Phagocytic Cells: Mechanisms of Bacterial Killing and Tissue Injury
[LIST_ITEM] Lymphocytes - 30% of WBC - Viral defenses - mostly nucleus, slightly larger than RBC
[LIST_ITEM] Basophils - 1% - blue in slides b/c of basic granules
[LIST_ITEM] Monocytes - 6% - big, kidney bean shaped nucleus
[LIST_ITEM] Spleen has lots of WBCs too
[LIST_ITEM] Degrade necrotic tissue and foreign antigens
[LIST_ITEM] If there for too long, can cause tissue damage
[LIST_ITEM] Tissue injury leads to inflammatory mediator and chemoattractant release
[LIST_ITEM] Inflammatory mediators make endothelium more sticky and permeable for cells to pass through (localization and migration)
[LIST_ITEM] Chemoattractants set up gradient that recruits neutrophils to site (localization)
[LIST_ITEM] Neutrophils can phagocytose, produce oxidants, release lysosomal granules
[LIST_ITEM] NADPH oxidase activation via min electron transport system
[LIST_ITEM] Most chemoattractants work via GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase signal transduction
[LIST_ITEM] Other receptors: receptors for collectins (mannose binding protein)
[LIST_ITEM] Neutrophil has receptors for opsonins that bind and then form phagosome --> phagolysosome
[LIST_ITEM] Once bacterium is in, NADPH oxidase makes H2O2 from O2 via O2- (superoxide anion)
[LIST_ITEM] w/o NADPH oxidase --> chronic granulomatous disease of childhood
[LIST_ITEM] Respiratory increase due to NADPH oxidase activity seen
[LIST_ITEM] NO synthase: makes NO radical from Arg --> vasodilation, intracellular cytotoxic agent, neurotransmitter; can be converted to make OH radicals or peroxynitrates
[LIST_ITEM] Oxidants/Proteases must be in balance w/ Antioxidants/Antiproteases
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Superoxide dismutase: takes superoxide anion and makes hydrogen peroxide
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Catalase: converts hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Glutathione peroxidase: takes peroxides and makes water, oxidized glutathione, and lipid-OH from LOOH
